head.title: A Preliminary Visual Orbit of BYÂ Draconis

article.h1: A Preliminary Visual Orbit of BYÂ Draconis

span.span: A.F.Â Boden11affiliation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center, California Institute of Technology 22affiliation: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology , B.F.Â Lane33affiliation: Geology and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology 22affiliation: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology

div.p: We report on the preliminary determination of the visual orbit of the double-lined spectroscopic binary system BYÂ Draconis with data obtained by the Palomar Testbed Interferometer in 1999. BYÂ Dra is a nearly equal-mass double-lined binary system whose spectroscopic orbit is well known. We have estimated the visual orbit of BYÂ Dra from our interferometric visibility data fit both separately and in conjunction with archival radial velocity data. Our BYÂ Dra orbit is in good agreement with the spectroscopic results. Due to the orbitâ€™s face-on orientation, the physical parameters implied by a combined fit to our visibility data and radial velocity data do not yet result in precise component masses and a system distance, but with continued interferometric monitoring we hope to improve the mass estimates to better than 10% determinations.

BYÂ Draconis (HDE 234677, Gl 719) is a well-studied nearby (âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 15 pc), multiple stellar system containing at least three objects. The A and B components form a short-period (6 d) late-type (K6Â Ve â€“ K7Â Vvar) binary system, whose spectroscopic orbit is well known (Bopp73 , hereafter BE73; Vogt79 , hereafter VF79; and Lucke80 , hereafter LM80). BY Dra is the prototype of a class of late-type flare stars characterized by photometric variability due to star spots, rapid rotation, and Ca II H and K emission lines. Like the BYÂ Dra system itself, a large fraction (>RELOP:greater-than> 85%, Bopp77 ; Bopp80 ) of BY Dra stars are known to be in short-period binary orbits. The rapid rotation of BY Dra A (period 3.83 d) that gives rise to the spotting and photometric variability is consistent with pseudosynchronus rotation with the A â€“ B orbital motion (Hut81 ; Hall86 ), but pseudosynchronization is disputed by Glebocki & Stawikowski (1995, 1997) who assert asynchronous rotation and roughly 30âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ} misalignment of the orbital/rotational angular momentum vectors.

Despite the fact that the BYÂ Dra A and B components are nearly equal mass, the system exhibits a significant brightness asymmetry in spectroscopic studies (VF79, LM80). VF79 attributes this to the hypothesis that A and B components of BY Dra are pre-main sequence objects (VF79, Bopp80 ), and are still in the contraction phase. VF79 argues for physical sizes of the A component in the range of 0.9 â€“ 1.4 Râ˜‰â˜‰FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\sun}, based primarily on rotation period and vâ¢sinâ¡iğ‘£ğ‘–italic-v TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-iv\sin i considerations. LM80 concur with the A component physical size argument from their vâ¢sinâ¡iğ‘£ğ‘–italic-v TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-iv\sin i measurements, estimating a 1.2 Râ˜‰â˜‰FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\sun} size for a sinâ¡iâ‰ˆğ‘–absentTRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-i RELOP:approximately-equals\sin i\approx 0.5 (presuming rotation/orbit spin alignment with pseudosynchronization, and our orbital inclination from Table 2). However, they continue by pointing out that if the A component macroturbulance were significantly larger than solar, then the vâ¢sinâ¡iğ‘£ğ‘–italic-v TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-iv\sin i measurements and the component diameters they are based on are biased high. If the pre-main sequence interpretation is correct, the BYÂ Dra components are additionally interesting as an examples of the transition region between pre and zero-age main sequence states.

BY Dra was detected as a hierachical triple system through common proper motion measurements of a BY Dra C component by Zuckerman et al.Â (1997); they find the C component separated by 17â€ from the A â€“ B pair. Zuckermanâ€™s photometry on the C component is consistent with an M5 main-sequence interpretation (Vğ‘‰italic-VV - Kğ¾italic-KK â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approx 6.2); assuming all three stars are coeval this clearly poses problems for the VF79 pre-main sequence hypothesis for the A and B components. At a projected physical separation of approximately 260 AU from the A â€“ B binary, the putative low-mass C component would have negligible dynamical influence on the A â€“ B binary motion. Further, the Hipparcos catalog (HIP97 ) implies the presence of at least one additional component as it lists BY Dra as having a circular photocentric orbital solution with 114 d period. This 114 d period is previously unreported in spectroscopic studies, and if correct it is difficult to understand why this motion was not previously detected.

Herein we report on a preliminary determination of the BY Dra A â€“ B system visual orbit from near-infrared, long-baseline interferometric measurements taken with the Palomar Testbed Interferometer (PTI). PTI is a 110-m Hğ»italic-HH (1.6Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum) and Kğ¾italic-KK-band (2.2 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum) interferometer located at Palomar Observatory, and described in detail elsewhere (Colavita99a ). PTI has a minimum fringe spacing of roughly 4 milliarcseconds (10-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} arcseconds, mas) in Kğ¾italic-KK-band at the sky position of BYÂ Dra, allowing resolution of the A â€“ B binary system.

The interferometric observable used for these measurements is the fringe contrast or visibility (squared, V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2}) of an observed brightness distribution on the sky. The reader is refered to one of the previous papers in this series (Boden99a ; Boden99b ; Boden2000 ) for descriptions of the V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} observables for binary stars.

BYÂ Dra was observed in conjunction with objects in our calibrator list (Table 1) by PTI in Kğ¾italic-KK-band (Î»âˆ¼2.2â¢Î¼similar-toğœ†2.2ğœ‡italic-lambda RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2.2 italic-mu\lambda\sim 2.2\mum) on 21 nights between 23 June 1999 and 21 October 1999, covering roughly 20 periods of the system. Additionally, BYÂ Dra was observed by PTI in Hğ»italic-HH-band (Î»âˆ¼1.6â¢Î¼similar-toğœ†1.6ğœ‡italic-lambda RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1.6 italic-mu\lambda\sim 1.6\mum) on 13 September, 2 October, and 20 October 1999. BYÂ Dra, along with calibration objects, was observed multiple times during each of these nights, and each observation, or scan, was approximately 130 sec long. For each scan we computed a mean V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} value from the scan data, and the error in the V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} estimate from the rms internal scatter. BYÂ Dra was always observed in combination with one or more calibration sources within âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 10âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ} on the sky. Table 1 lists the relevant physical parameters for the calibration objects. We have calibrated the V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} data by methods discussed in Boden et al.Â (1998). Our 1999 observations of BYÂ Dra result in 67 calibrated visibility measurements (50 in Kğ¾italic-KK-band, 17 in Hğ»italic-HH-band). One notable aspect of our BYÂ Dra observations is that its high declination (51âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ}) relative to our Palomar site (33âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ} latitude) puts it at the extreme Northern edge of the delay line range on our N-S baseline (Colavita99a ), implying extremely limited u-vğ‘¢ğ‘£italic-u ADDOP:minus italic-vu-v coverage on BYÂ Dra. To our PTI visibilities we have added 44 double-lined radial velocity measurments: 14 from BE73, seven from VF79, and 23 CORAVEL measurements from LM80.

figure.figcaption: Table 1: PTI BYÂ Dra Calibration Objects Considered in our Analysis. The relevant parameters for our two calibration objects are summarized. The apparent diameter values are determined from effective temperature and bolometric flux estimates based on archival broad-band photometry, and visibility measurements with PTI.

div.p: As in previous papers in this series (Boden99a ; Boden99b ; Boden2000 ) the estimation of the BYÂ Dra visual orbit is made by fitting a Keplerian orbit model directly to the calibrated (narrow-band and synthetic wide-band) V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} and RV data on BYÂ Dra; because of the limited u-vğ‘¢ğ‘£italic-u ADDOP:minus italic-vu-v coverage in our data derivation of intermediate separation vector models is impossible. The fit is non-linear in the Keplerian orbital elements, and is therefore performed by non-linear least-squares methods with a parallel exhaustive search strategy to determine the global minimum in the chi-squared manifold. The reader is refered to the previous papers for futher details on our orbit estimation procedures.

Figure 1 depicts the relative visual orbit of the BYÂ Dra system, with the primary component rendered at the origin, and the secondary component rendered at periastron. We have indicated the phase coverage of our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} data on the relative orbit with heavy lines; our data samples most phases of the orbit well, leading to a reliable orbit determination. The apparent inclination is very near the estimate given by VF79 based on the primary rotation period, assumed size, and assumption of parallel orbital/rotational angular momentum alignment. The orbit is seen approximately 30âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ} from a face-on perspective, which makes physical parameter determination difficult (Â§5).

img.figcaption: Figure 1: Visual Orbit of BYÂ Dra. The relative visual orbit model of BYÂ Dra is shown, with the primary and secondary objects rendered at T00FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{0} (periastron). The heavy lines along the relative orbit indicate areas where we have orbital phase coverage in our PTI data (they are not separation vector estimates); our data samples most phases of the orbit well, leading to a reliable orbit determination. Component diameter values are estimated (see discussion in Â§Â 5), and are rendered to scale.

div.p: Figure 2 illustrates comparisons between our PTI V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} and archival RV data and our orbit model. In Figure 2a six consecutive nights of Kğ¾italic-KK-band visibility data and visibility predictions from the best-fit model are shown, inset with fit residuals along the bottom. That there are only 1 â€“ 3 data points in each of the nights follows from the brief time each night that BYÂ Dra is simultaneously within both delay and zenith angle limits. Figure 2b gives the phased archival RV data and model predictions, inset with a histogram of RV fit residuals. The fit quality is consistent with previous PTI orbit analyses.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Joint V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2}/Radial Velocity Fit of BYÂ Dra. a: Six consecutive nights of V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} data on BYÂ Dra, and best-fit model predictions. b: Phased archival RV data (BE73, VF79, LM80) and RV predictions from our best-fit orbital model. Inset is a histogram of RV residuals to the fit model.

div.p: Spectroscopic orbit parameters (from VF79 and LM80) and our visual and spectroscopic orbit parameters of the BYÂ Dra system are summarized in Table 2. We give the results of separate fits to only our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} data (our â€œV2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2}-only Fitâ€ solution), and a simultaneous fit to our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} data and the archival double-lined radial velocities â€“ both with component diameters constrained as noted above. All uncertainties in parameters are quoted at the one sigma level. We see good statistical agreement between all the derived orbital parameters with the exception of the LM80 period estimate.

semantics.annotation: OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start VERTBAR:| italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ARG:end
OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start VERTBAR:| italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ARG:end

figure.figcaption: Table 2: Orbital Parameters for BYÂ Dra. Summarized here are the apparent orbital parameters for the BYÂ Dra system as determined by VF79, LM80, and PTI. We give two separate fits to our data, with and without including archival double-lined radial velocities in the fit. Quantities given in italics are constrained to the listed values in our model fits. We have quoted the longitude of the ascending node parameter (Î©Î©Omega\Omega) as the angle between local East and the orbital line of nodes measured positive in the direction of local North. Due to the degeneracy in our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} observable there is a 180âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ} ambiguity in Î©Î©Omega\Omega; by convention we quote it in the interval of [0:180). We quote mean absolute V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} and RV residuals in the fits, |RV2|Â¯Â¯subscriptğ‘…superscriptğ‘‰2OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start VERTBAR:| italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ARG:end\overline{|R_{V^{2}}|} and |RRâ¢V|Â¯Â¯subscriptğ‘…ğ‘…ğ‘‰OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start VERTBAR:| italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ARG:end\overline{|R_{RV}|} respectively.

div.p: The Hipparcos catalog lists a circular photocentric orbital solution for BYÂ Dra with a 114 day period (HIP97 ), presumably in addition to the well-established 6 d period A â€“ B motion. As noted above it is difficult to reconcile this hypothesis with the quality of the existing short-period spectroscopic orbit solutions from VF79 and LM80. However if the A â€“ B system indeed did have a companion with this period, unlike BYÂ Dra C it would lie within PTIâ€™s 1â€ primary beam, and if sufficiently luminous it would bias the visibility measurements used in our BYÂ Dra A â€“ B visual orbit model. We see no indications of this in our orbital solutions; the quality of our BYÂ Dra visual orbit solution is consistent with our results on other systems. But it remains possible we have misinterpreted our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} data in the binary star model fit, and we are motivated to consider the 114-d periodicity hypothesis in the archival RV data.

We note that the Hipparcos model is a photocentric orbit, and therefore calls for the A â€“ B system to exhibit a reflex motion with radius â‰¥RELOP:greater-than-or-equals\geq 0.05 AU at the putative distance of BYÂ Dra. The 114-d orbit hypothesis is at high inclination (113âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ}), and therefore would produce a radial velocity semi-amplitude for the A â€“ B system barycenter â‰¥RELOP:greater-than-or-equals\geq 3.95 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. This value is large compared to fit residuals observed by VF79 and LM80 in their spectroscopic orbital solutions (and by ourselves in the joint fit with our visibilities; TableÂ 2), suggesting the 114-d motion hypothesis is unlikely.

To quantify this issue we have considered Lomb-Scargle periodogram analyses of the LM80 BYÂ Dra radial velocity data. We have chosen to use the LM80 data because it is the more precise sample, yielding an rms residual of roughly 0.5 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} in our A â€“ B orbit analysis. Figure 3 gives periodograms of the LM80 primary and secondary radial velocity data. First, Figure 3a gives a periodogram of the primary and secondary RV data, with probability of false alarm levels (Pfâ¢ağ‘“ğ‘FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f italic-a FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{fa}) as noted. As expected, both component lines exhibit a significant periodicity at the observed A â€“ B orbit frequency of approximately (6 d)-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} (indicated by vertical line). In the same plot we sample the frequency of the 114-d orbit hypothesis, and no comparable periodicity is evident on the scale of the A â€“ B motion.

Presuming the 114-d motion hypothesis might be superimposed on the 6-d A â€“ B orbit, in Figure 3b we give a periodogram of the LM80 primary and secondary RV fit residuals to the 6-d hypothesis fit. In Figure 3b we have adjusted to range of the periodogram to finely sample the frequency range around the (114 d)-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} hypothesis (indicated by vertical line). No significant periodicity is noted at this or any other frequency. The LM80 RV dataset spans roughly 400 days, so a 4 km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1} amplitude periodicity in this dataset should have been evident in our analysis. Given these considerations, it seems unlikely that our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} measurements and A â€“ B orbit model are affected by the presence of a third luminous body.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: Lomb â€“ Scargle Periodograms on LM80 BYÂ Dra Radial Velocity Data. To assess the 114-d orbit hypothesis for an additional companion to the BYÂ Dra A â€“ B system we have performed Lomb â€“ Scargle periodogram analysis on double-lined BYÂ Dra data from LM80. Top: standard periodograms on primary and secondary RV data from the LM80 dataset. Statistically significant response is seen at the well-known 6 d A â€“ B period (vertical line). Bottom: Low-frequency periodogram of the residuals of the LM80 data to the best-fit A â€“ B orbit model. No significant response is evident at the putative 114 d period (vertical line).

div.p: The combination of the double-lined spectroscopic orbit and relative visual orbit allow us to estimate the BY Dra A â€“ B component masses and system distance. However, because of the nearly face-on geometry of the A â€“ B orbit, the accuracy of our inclination estimate, and consequently the component mass estimates and system distance estimate, is relatively poor. The low-inclination geometry is particularly difficult for astrometric studies because the astrometric observable (V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} in this case) becomes highly insensitive to small changes in the inclination Euler angle. Table 3 lists the physical parameters we estimate from our Full-Fit orbit solution. The mass estimates are in a reasonable range for stars of this type but are formally crude â€“ roughly 24% 1-Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma uncertainties, as is the system distance estimate â€“ roughly 8% 1-Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma. In both cases the dominant error is the inclination; to improve these mass and distance estimates by a factor of two we must improve the inclination estimate by a factor of two. The orbital parallax with its large error is in 1-Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma agreement with the Hipparcos triginometric determination of 60.9 Â±plus-or-minusADDOP:plus-or-minus\pm 0.75 mas, but we note that the Hipparcos solution was derived jointly with the 3 mas, 114-d orbital hypothesis that we believe to be suspect (Â§4).

semantics.annotation: italic-pi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-r italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

figure.figcaption: Table 3: Physical Parameters for BYÂ Dra. Summarized here are the physical parameters for the BYÂ Dra A â€“ B system as derived primarily from the Full-Fit solution orbital parameters in Table 2. Quantities listed in italics (i.e. the component diameters, see text discussion) are constrained to the listed values in our model fits.

div.p: Table 3 also gives component absolute magnitudes and Vğ‘‰italic-VV - Kğ¾italic-KK color indices derived from archival broad-band photometry, our Hğ»italic-HH and Kğ¾italic-KK component relative magnitudes, the LM80 Vğ‘‰italic-VV relative magnitude, and our system distance estimate. The component color indices are unaffected by errors in the system distance, and seem to be in good agreement with the color indices expected from stars in this mass range and the classical spectral typing of the BYÂ Dra system. The absolute magnitudes are somewhat uncertain from the relatively poor distance estimate, but suggest a modest discrepancy with the mass-luminosity models of Baraffe et al (1998, BCAH98). As depicted in Figure 4, both components appear roughly 0.5 â€“ 1 mag brighter at Vğ‘‰italic-VV and Kğ¾italic-KK than the BCAH98 models evaluated at our model masses would predict. The cause for this discrepancy could be abnormally large component sizes suggested by VF79, or the component masses are underestimated in our analysis. Clearly we need to improve our orbit model so as to further constrain the BY Dra component parameters.

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: BY Dra Components in Mass/Luminosity Space. Here we give the positions of the A and B BY Dra components in observable Mass/MVğ‘‰FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{V} (upper pannel) and Mass/MKğ¾FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{K} (lower pannel) spaces (an emulation of Figure 3 from BCAH98), superimposing low mass objects from Henry & McCarthy (1993) and Andersen (1990) and BCAH98 solar-metalicity model tracks at ages of 1099FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9}, 1088FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{8}, and 1077FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{7} yrs. While our mass determinations are currently too crude to be definitive, both components appear over-luminous compared to the BCAH98 models, and it is difficult to reconcile the deviations with age effects.

div.p: To assess the VF79 component size/pre-main sequence hypothesis, the most interesting measurement of the BYÂ Dra A â€“ B system would be unequivocal measurements of the component diameters. Unfortunately our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} data are as yet insufficient to determine these diameters independently. Canonical sizes of 1.0 Râ˜‰â˜‰FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\sun} and 0.8 Râ˜‰â˜‰FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\sun} (indicated by model effective temperatures and our IR flux ratios) yield angular diameters of approximately 0.6 and 0.5 mas for the A and B components respectively. At these sizes neither the Hğ»italic-HH nor Kğ¾italic-KK-band fringe spacings of PTI sufficiently resolve the components to independently determine component sizes. Consequently we have constrained our orbital solutions to these 0.6 and 0.5 mas model values. Our data does in fact prefer the slightly smaller primary component diameter to the larger 1.2 Râ˜‰â˜‰FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start â˜‰ FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{\sun} size implied by VF79 and LM80 vâ¢sinâ¡iğ‘£ğ‘–italic-v TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-iv\sin i and rotational period measurements. However either primary model diameter is possible with the expected systematic V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} calibration errors. Additional data we will collect in the coming year (see below) may well place interesting upper limits on the component sizes, but unambiguous resolution of the BYÂ Dra A and B components will have to wait for a longer baseline infrared interferometer; most likely the CHARA array currently under construction on Mt.Â Wilson 111http://www.chara.gsu.edu/CHARAArray/chara_array.html

The prospects for improving the BYÂ Dra orbital model in general, and the orbital inclination estimate in particular are reasonable. To acheive 10% mass determinations on the BYÂ Dra components we will need to reduce the inclination uncertainty to approximately 1.5âˆ˜FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ}, which implies a rough quadrupling of the PTI visibility data on BYÂ Dra, or an improvement of our V2superscriptğ‘‰2italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{2} measurement precision by a factor of two on a data set of similar size to that already collected. Both are plausible; PTI is expected to be in normal operation for at least another season, and hardware upgrades to the PTI fringe camera are planned and should provide significant improvements in sensitivity.

section.div: The work described in this paper was performed at the Infrared Processing and Analysis Center, California Institute of Technology, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Interferometer data were obtained at Palomar Observatory using the NASA Palomar Testbed Interferometer, supported by NASA contracts to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Science operations with PTI are conducted through the efforts of the PTI Collaboration (http://huey.jpl.nasa.gov/palomar/ptimembers.html), and we acknowledge the invaluable contributions of our PTI colleagues. We further acknowledge I.N.Â Reid (UPenn) for the compilation of mass-luminosity data on Henry & McCarthy and Andersen objects. This research has made use of the Simbad database, operated at CDS, Strasbourg, France.
